en_results_raw: the biting wind, gave a sudden gasp of pain. In his nostrils was the smell of the Ministry of Truth, where he worked as a clerk. The Ministry, a colossal pyramidal structure of white concrete and steel, loomed above London, a city that never slept, its inhabitants living in a state of perpetual alertness under the ever-watchful eye of Big Brother. The telescreen in every room, every street corner, every home, was a constant reminder of the Party's omnipresence, its ability to see and hear everything. Winston's job involved rewriting historical records to match the Party's ever-changing narrative, a task that required a willingness to forget the past and accept the Party's version of reality. He knew that outside, the streets were filled with people hurrying to and fro, their faces mask-like, their expressions empty, their minds focused on the day's quota of work or the evening's entertainment provided by the State. The clocks striking thirteen was a peculiar anomaly, a reminder of the Party's control over time itself, manipulating it to suit its needs. Winston's thoughts, however, were not on the Party's whims or the cold wind. He was haunted by a dream, a recurring vision of a world where truth was not a crime, where individuality was not a sin. In this dream, he was walking through a lush, green countryside, the air filled with the scent of wildflowers, the sun warm on his skin, a stark contrast to the reality of his existence. He longed for a life unshackled by Big Brother's watchful eye, a life where he could love and be loved, where he could express his own thoughts and feelings without fear of punishment. But such thoughts were dangerous, a sign of thoughtcrime, and could lead to his arrest and disappearance into the Ministry's depths, never to be seen again. As he stood there, the cold biting deeper into his bones, Winston made a silent vow. He would continue to resist, to hold onto his individuality, to cherish his dreams of a different world, no matter the cost.

He hesitated, the weight of his actions and the consequences they carried pressing down on him. The door creaked as he pushed it open, revealing the dimly lit corridor beyond. He stepped into the hallway, the silence of the building enveloping him like a shroud. The air was stale, carrying the faint scent of mold and the distant echo of footsteps from somewhere above. He knew he had to be cautious; the Thought Police were ever-present, lurking in the shadows, ready to pounce on any sign of dissent. With each step, Winston felt the cold floor beneath his feet, a stark reminder of the reality he lived in—a reality where freedom was a distant memory, and the Party's control was absolute. Yet, in that moment, he held onto a flicker of hope, a tiny ember of defiance burning within him. He had to believe that his actions, no matter how small, could contribute to the eventual downfall of Big Brother's tyranny. The diary, with its bold declaration, was a symbol of his resistance, a testament to his individuality in a world that sought to erase it. As he moved deeper into the building, he was acutely aware of the risks he was taking. The Party's surveillance was omnipresent, with telescreens watching and listening to every move. Yet, in his heart, Winston felt a strange sense of liberation. He was no longer alone in his thoughts of rebellion; there was another, perhaps many others, who shared his desire for freedom. This realization gave him a newfound strength, pushing him forward despite the fear that gnawed at him. He had to trust that his actions, however insignificant they might seem, were part of a larger movement, a collective resistance against the oppressive regime. The diary, with its defiant words, was his first step towards joining that movement. As he navigated the dimly lit corridors, Winston clung to the belief that change was possible, that the grip of Big Brother could be loosened, if not entirely broken. The path ahead was fraught with danger, but for the first time in a long while, Winston felt a glimmer of hope. He was no longer just a passive observer in the dystopian world he lived in; he was an active participant in the struggle for freedom.

en_results_raw: of the number of dead, the news flashed on to a report of a huge explosion in the prole district, a place where the Party said there was nothing except poverty and dirt. The explosion had destroyed several hundred houses, and several thousand people had been buried in the ruins. It was announced that it was an accident due to the carelessness of a group of prole mechanics who had been using explosives. It was not a rebellion, it was not a plot; it was merely an accident. But a few people, including Winston, doubted this explanation. They remembered the old man with the withered arm who had been taken away after the Hate Week demonstrations, and the rumours that had circulated about him afterwards. It was said that he had been caught red-handed tampering with a bomb, though whether he had actually done so or not was uncertain. The Party's story might be true, but it was also possible that the explosion had been planned and the mechanics framed as a warning to the proles. In any case, the effect was the same: the proles had been reminded yet again that they were entirely at the mercy of the Party, which could crush them like insects if it chose.

en_first_half: The telescreen was giving forth an ear-splitting whistle which continued on the same note for thirty seconds. It was nought seven fifteen, getting-up time for office workers. Winston wrenched his body out of bed—naked, for a member of the Outer Party received only three thousand clothing coupons annually, and a suit of pajamas was six hundred—and seized a dingy singlet and a pair of shorts that were lying across a chair.
en_second_half: The Physical Jerks would begin in three minutes. The next moment he was doubled up by a violent coughing fit which nearly always attacked him soon after waking up. It emptied his lungs so completely that he could only begin breathing again by lying on his back and taking a series of deep gasps. His veins had swelled with the effort of the cough, and the varicose ulcer had started itching.

The telescreen fell silent, replaced by a mechanical voice announcing the day's schedule. en_results_raw: He pulled them on hurriedly, feeling the coarse fabric scratch against his skin, a sensation he had learned to associate with the start of another day in the Party's service. The telescreen fell silent, replaced by a mechanical voice announcing the day's schedule. Winston stood in front of the mirror, his reflection showing a man in his mid-thirties with a weary, slack face and ragged hair that seemed to have lost its color. The Party's propaganda was everywhere, even in the mirror's frame, which bore the inscription, "I LOVE BIG BROTHER, AND I WILL WORK HARD FOR THE PARTY." He grimaced at the words, a habitual reaction that offered him no comfort. The smell of boiled cabbage and old rag mats filled the air, a reminder of the simple, monotonous breakfast he would consume in the canteen. He picked up his gray cloth cap, its peak slightly frayed, and put it on his head. The cap was a symbol of his membership in the Outer Party, a privilege that came with a meager allowance and the burden of constant surveillance. As he stepped out of his small, sparsely furnished room, he knew that the telescreen in the living quarters across the corridor would be watching him, its single, unblinking eye ever-present. The hallway was dimly lit, the walls a dull battleship gray, and the floors a cold, uninviting concrete. The sound of footsteps echoed as his neighbors began their morning routines, each one a faceless member of the Party, all bound by the same obligations and the same lack of individuality. Winston made his way to the hallway's exit, stepping into the corridor that led to the communal bathroom and the canteen. The air was heavy with the scent of the morning's first cigarette smoke, a testament to the Party's allowance of a few precious minutes of personal time before the day's work began. He joined the line of people moving towards the bathroom, each person's face a mask of resignation or, in the lucky few, a hint of contentment. The thought of the day's work ahead weighed heavily on him, the endless stream of reports to write, the statistics to manipulate, and the ever-present task of ensuring that his loyalty to Big Brother remained unshaken. The Party's control was absolute, its reach into every aspect of life inescapable. Yet, amidst the uniformity and oppression, Winston harbored a secret rebellion, a flicker of dissent that he kept hidden beneath the surface, aware that to express it would be to invite the Party's swift and merciless retribution. As he finally reached the bathroom, he caught a glimpse of himself in the mirror, his face set in a mask of calm, a facade that would last until the evening's mandatory evening Hate session. Behind the façade, however, lay a tumult of thoughts and emotions, a swirling vortex of fear, anger, and a desperate yearning for something beyond the Party's grasp. The day would unfold, and with it, the inexorable march towards an uncertain future, a future where the only certainty was the Party's unyielding grip on power.

en_first_half: The pain of the coughing fit had not quite driven out of Winston’s mind the impression made by his dream, and the rhythmic movements of the exercise restored it somewhat. As he mechanically shot his arms back and forth, wearing on his face the look of grim enjoyment which was considered proper during the Physical Jerks, he was struggling to think his way backward into the dim period of his early childhood. It was extraordinarily difficult. Beyond the late Fifties everything faded. When there were no external records that you could refer to,
en_second_half: even the outline of your own life lost its sharpness. You remembered huge events which had quite probably not happened, you remembered the detail of incidents without being able to recapture their atmosphere, and there were long blank periods to which you could assign nothing. Everything had been different then. Even the names of countries, and their shapes on the map, had been different. Airstrip One, for instance, had not been so called in those days: it had been called England or Britain, though London, he felt fairly certain, had always been called London.
en_results: he had to rely entirely on memory, and after the fifties memories grew dimmer and less reliable. The earlier the date, the vaguer it seemed. He tried to recall the texture of the air, the quality of light, the feeling of the ground under bare feet, the smell of the world when Britain was still a green and inhabited country. But it was all elusive, like the glassy surface of a pond into which a stone has been thrown, rippling outward but leaving no permanent mark. He could remember his mother's voice, but not individual words, only the tone and inflection, the warmth
en_results_raw: he had to rely entirely on memory, and after the fifties memories grew dimmer and less reliable. The earlier the date, the vaguer it seemed. He tried to recall the texture of the air, the quality of light, the feeling of the ground under bare feet, the smell of the world when Britain was still a green and inhabited country. But it was all elusive, like the glassy surface of a pond into which a stone has been thrown, rippling outward but leaving no permanent mark. He could remember his mother's voice, but not individual words, only the tone and inflection, the warmth and the authority. His father was a dim figure, larger than life but without distinct features. Winston's earliest memories were of his mother, but they were not clear. He remembered her face, yes, but it was not a face that he could visualize separately from the rest of her. It was as though her face changed its expression with every tiny movement she made, so that there was no one expression that could be pinned down. He remembered her voice singing some old song, a fragment of rhyme that he could not recover, and her body rocking to and fro as she carried him. He remembered the feel of her hair, which was always warm, and the smell of her, which was only faintly like anything he had ever smelled since. He remembered the taste of her milk, which was different from the taste of the Party's Victory Gin, and the sensation of being fed, which was entirely unlike the mechanical process of drinking from a cup. Yet these memories were not enough. They were fragmentary, and they did not add up to a coherent picture of the past. The Party had succeeded in wiping out a whole period from Winston's life. It was as though a part of his personal history had been surgically removed, leaving only scattered fragments. The more he tried to reconstruct it, the more phantom-like it became. He wondered whether the Party had not done the same for the whole population; whether other people too had their five-year stretches in the orphanages, or the dreary years at the provincial schools, wiped out and replaced by a false memory of having been at the Public Schools, or in the Navy, or in the Party itself. The more he thought about it, the more likely it seemed. The Party was not content with controlling the present; it had to control the past, to alter memories, to rewrite history. That was a frightening thought. If the past could be wiped out, if all records could be falsified, if the evidence of a thousand years could be wiped clean, then the possibility was open to the Party to declare that two and two made five, and you would have to believe it. Your own memory was no longer a trusted guide, but a series of false snapshots, each tailor-made to fit the Party's version of events. The Physical Jerks ended, and the class filed out of the gymnasium, their faces still flushed with the exertion, their minds still reeling from the enforced orthodoxy of their exercises. As Winston walked home, the streets emptying out after the day's work, he felt a twinge of nostalgia for the lost world of his childhood, a world that might never have existed outside his dreams. He wondered if somewhere, beyond the reach of the Party, there was a place where the past was not altered, where true memory endured, and where a man could still know what three plus three made.

vi_results_raw: of a frantic evacuation. The sound of explosions was distant yet unmistakable, a deep rumble that vibrated through the ground. Winston's small hands clutched tightly to his father's shirt, his eyes wide with fear and confusion. He didn't understand the urgency, the panic in his father's face, or the strange words spoken in hurried whispers. People around them moved like ants, scurrying in every direction, their faces etched with terror. The air was thick with smoke and the acrid smell of burning rubber and fuel. Amidst the chaos, Winston's father managed to convey a simple yet profound message: "Stay close and keep your head down." These words became a mantra, a lifeline in the sea of panic. As they moved, Winston's focus narrowed to his father's face, to the reassuring grip on his hand, and to the rhythm of their hurried steps. The journey felt endless, each moment blending into the next, marked only by the continuous roar of distant explosions and the sharp, stinging fear that gripped everyone's heart. Eventually, they reached a bomb shelter, a dark, damp place that offered a semblance of safety. Inside, the air was cooler, and the noise of the outside world was muffled. Winston's father sat down, pulling Winston onto his lap, wrapping his arms around him protectively. "It's going to be okay," he whispered, though his voice trembled. Winston, too young to fully grasp the gravity of the situation, clung to his father, feeling the steady heartbeat beneath his cheek. He fell asleep to the sound of his father's breathing, a rhythmic lullaby that promised safety and security in a world suddenly turned upside down. When Winston awoke, the shelter was filled with the subdued sounds of people talking in hushed tones, the distant echo of artillery fire, and the occasional cough or sniffle. The war, it seemed, was still raging outside, but within the confines of the shelter, a fragile peace reigned. As days turned into weeks, the routine of the shelter life became familiar. People shared what little they had, stories were told to pass the time, and bonds formed in the shared struggle for survival. Winston, too young to remember the horrors outside, grew up within these walls, his earliest memories interwoven with the scent of damp earth, the sound of distant explosions, and the warmth of his father's embrace. The war, a constant presence in the world outside, became a distant memory for Winston, a chapter in history he would learn about one day. For now, it was enough to know that in the darkest of times, there was always a place to find safety, a father to hold him close, and the promise of a future that, though uncertain, was worth fighting for.

It was a rule that every citizen must buy a certain amount of books and periodicals, which were issued by the State and had no intellectual content. The books were all alike. With the exception of the Sex Manual, which contained illustrations, they were all composed of the same words, arranged in the same pattern. The words were always simple words, with the familiar 5-letter words being the commonest. The sentence structure was simple, the vocabulary limited, and the style concrete. The books were intended to instill only one idea: that of the Party and the supremacy of its leader, Big Brother. They were all designed to prevent independent thought. The moment one heard anything likely to stimulate thought, one automatically rejected it. The consciousness of differentness, of being at odds with the majority, was a constant presence in one’s mind. It was even possible that one was never alone in this. The people around one probably had similar feelings, but one could never be sure, for the face always remained inscrutable. The only escape was in the Party itself. The Party was everywhere. It saw you or heard you wherever you went. The eyes of Big Brother were upon you. The Thought Police would get you if you let them. In your own home, you were never alone. The telescreen could be turned off only by a complicated procedure, and this was watched. The smallest things could betray you. A flicker of expression, a hesitancy at a crossing, a lapse in attention. They were all evidence. The truth was whatever the Party said it was. You had to accept it, you had no choice. The past was altered, history was rewritten, and the truth was whatever the Party chose to make it so. The Party’s power was absolute and complete. It was a power that directly denied the very existence of individuality. The individual was only a cell in the body of the Party. It was not even like a family. The members of the Party were not related by blood or marriage. They were united by a common purpose, the preservation of the Party and the hatred of its enemies. The enemy of the moment was Eurasia, a vast land stretching from the Arctic to the Indian Ocean, ruled by a man known as the Great Leader. The Party had told them that Eurasia was more powerful than Oceania, which was their own country, and that the war with Eurasia had been going on for years. The war was not fought in the traditional way, with armies meeting on the battlefield. It was a war of attrition, a continuous state of hatred and destruction. The Party kept the war going by manipulating the truth. The enemy varied from time to time. Sometimes it was Eurasia that was the enemy; sometimes it was Eastasia. The enemy of one month might be the ally of the next. This was all part of the strategy. The truth was whatever the Party said it was, and the Party constantly altered the truth. The past was no guide. The future was whatever the Party chose to make it. The individual’s duty was to work and obey. The individual’s greatest fear was that of being caught committing thoughtcrime. Thoughtcrime did not entail death—it was worse than death. Thoughtcrime was the crime of thinking itself. The Party sought to extinguish the mind. Con la mente distraída entre el pensamiento de pagar la deuda inmediata y la incertidumbre de cómo hacerlo, no se dio cuenta de que su decisión de no gastar el dinero en una nueva ropa había sido más que un simple acto de austeridad. En realidad, era una manifestación de su miedo a la incertidumbre, a la pérdida de control que suponía adquirir algo nuevo. Mientras buscaba desesperadamente en el sofá, sus dedos se entrecortaron entre billetes desgastados y tarjetas de crédito, recordando cada gasto irresponsable y cada promesa a sí mismo de cambiar. "Debo hacer algo", pensó, su voz interior altamente nerviosa. "Debo tomar control de esto". Así, con la determinación creciente, Winston comenzó a planificar, no solo cómo pagar la deuda, sino cómo cambiar su comportamiento financiero para evitar que una situación similar se repitiera. Su primer paso fue buscar información en línea sobre cómo gestionar el dinero, encontrando artículos sobre el giro del presupuesto y las tácticas de ahorro efectiva. A medida que avanzaba en su plan, Winston comenzó a sentir un cambio en su estado de ánimo. El miedo a la incertidumbre empezó a desvanecerse ante la claridad que le proporcionaba el conocimiento adquirido. "Soy capaz de esto", pensó, con una confianza renovada. "No voy a permitir que el miedo me domine". Con cada paso adelante en su plan, Winston no solo estaba lidiando con su deuda actual, sino también construyendo un camino hacia una vida más estable y menos temerosa de los peligros financieros. Su decisión de buscar ayuda y aprender sobre finanzas personalas no solo le proporcionó la solución a su problema inmediato, sino que también le enseñó valiosas lecciones sobre autosuficiencia y responsabilidad financiera. "La clave no es evitar los desafíos", reflexionó Winston, mientras revisaba su presupuesto actualmente bien organizado, "sino aprender a enfrentarlos de manera efectiva". Con cada día que pasaba, Winston se convirtía no solo en un individuo más financiamente sano, sino también en alguien más fuerte y resiliente ante las adversidades de la vida.

en_first_half: He remembered how once he had been walking down a crowded street when a tremendous shout of hundreds of voices—women’s voices—had burst from a side street a little way ahead. It was a great formidable cry of anger and despair, a deep, loud “Oh-o-o-o-oh!” that went humming on like the reverberation of a bell. His heart had leapt. It’s started! he had thought. A riot! The proles are breaking loose at last! When he had reached the spot it was to see a mob of two or three hundred women crowding round the stalls of a street market, with faces as tragic as though they had been the doomed passengers on a sinking ship. But at this moment the general despair broke down into a multitude of individual quarrels. It appeared that one of the stalls had been selling tin saucepans. They were wretched, flimsy
en_second_half: things, but cooking pots of any kind were always difficult to get. Now the supply had unexpectedly given out. The successful women, bumped and jostled by the rest, were trying to make off with their saucepans while dozens of others clamored round the stall, accusing the stallkeeper of favoritism and of having more saucepans somewhere in reserve. There was a fresh outburst of yells. Two bloated women, one of them with her hair coming down, had got hold of the same saucepan and were trying to tear it out of one another’s hands. For a moment they were both tugging, and then the handle came off. Winston watched them disgustedly. And yet, just for a moment, what almost frightening power had sounded in that cry from only a few hundred throats! Why was it that they could never shout like that about anything that mattered?

en_results_raw: was coming. The explosion, when it came, was not nearly so loud as one would have expected from a rocket bomb of that size. It was a deep, rumbling noise that made the windows rattle. Winston picked himself up and peered cautiously through the smoke that was already beginning to rise from the spot where the rocket had fallen. He could see the proles emerging from their houses, gazing curiously at the crater. Some of them were already running towards it, their faces full of excitement and morbid curiosity. The children were the worst; they screeched and shouted, eager to get a closer look at the devastation. The adults, though more restrained, were equally fascinated. It was a rare event for a rocket to fall in their part of the town, and they treated it as a kind of public spectacle. The authorities would undoubtedly come and clear up the mess later, but for the moment the proles were in control. Winston watched them for a few moments longer, then turned away and made his way back inside. He felt a twinge of envy at their ignorance, their simple, straightforward lives. They were not tormented by the weight of the Party's surveillance or the constant fear of betrayal. They lived and died without understanding the true nature of the world they inhabited. In a way, they were the truly free people. The rocket bomb had not harmed them; it had only reminded them of the war that was still raging outside, a war that they had largely forgotten. In the streets below, life went on as usual. The shops would soon reopen, the markets would fill with people, and the hum of daily existence would resume. The proles, for all their simplicity, were the backbone of the Party's power. They provided the labor, the numbers, and the unquestioning loyalty that kept the Party in control. And yet, they were also the Party's greatest threat, with their potential for rebellion simmering just beneath the surface. Winston wondered, as he always did, what would happen if the proles ever woke up. Would they rise up and overthrow the Party, or would they simply continue their aimless existence, never realizing their own strength? The question remained unanswered, as it always would. For now, the rocket bomb was just another event in the endless cycle of war and peace, destruction and rebuilding. In the end, it changed nothing.

en_second_half: street took a sharp turn and then ended in a flight of steps which led down into a sunken alley where a few stallkeepers were selling tired-looking vegetables. en_results_raw: sound grew louder as he approached, and he could see the mouths moving, could almost hear what they were saying. It was a crowd of people, a crowd large enough to be significant, gathered around something. As he drew nearer, he saw that they were clustered around a small boy who was standing on a pile of old newspapers, his face a picture of concentration. The boy was speaking, his voice carrying above the surrounding noise, and the people were listening, some with interest, others with amusement. Winston watched for a moment longer, then turned away. The sight of the boy, so young and yet so bold, speaking out in a world where truth was suppressed, stirred something within him. It was a reminder that the Party's control was not absolute, that there were still individuals who dared to think and speak freely, albeit in small, scattered pockets of resistance. The proles, the lowest class in Oceania, were the Party's enemy, yet they were also its potential saviors. They were the majority, the common people, untamed and uncontrolled, their lives untouched by the Party's propaganda and surveillance. If there was a chance to overthrow the regime, it lay with them. Winston's faith in the proles was not blind optimism; it was a belief rooted in the simple fact that the Party could not reach into every home, could not erase every spark of rebellion. The proles lived outside the Party's grasp, in a world where truth could still flicker to life. It was this hope, however fragile, that sustained him. He continued down the street, his heart heavy with the weight of responsibility and the knowledge that the path ahead was fraught with danger. Yet, he knew he could not turn back. The Party's tyranny could not be challenged without courage, and Winston had already chosen his course. He would work within the Ministry of Truth, manipulating facts and history as the Party demanded, all the while nurturing the ember of rebellion in his chest. He would be a spy for the proles, gathering information and spreading seeds of dissent wherever he could. The boy on the newspapers had shown him that change was possible, that the human spirit could not be extinguished completely. And so, with a renewed sense of purpose, Winston walked on, his mind already racing with plans and schemes, ready to play his part in the fragile, yet hopeful, resistance against the Party.

en_first_half: Winston sat back against the window sill. It was no use going on. He was about to buy some more beer when the old man suddenly got up and shuffled rapidly into the stinking urinal at the side of the room. The extra half-liter was already working on him. Winston sat for a minute or two gazing at his empty glass, and hardly noticed when his feet carried him out into the street again. Within twenty years at the most, he reflected, the huge and simple question, “Was life better before the Revolution than it is now?” would have ceased once and for all to be answerable. But in effect it was unanswerable even now, since the few scattered survivors
en_second_half: from the ancient world were incapable of comparing one age with another. They remembered a million useless things, a quarrel with a workmate, a hunt for a lost bicycle pump, the expression on a long-dead sister’s face, the swirls of dust on a windy morning seventy years ago; but all the relevant facts were outside the range of their vision. They were like the ant, which can see small objects but not large ones. The air was stuffy and close, and the atmosphere of the place was one of long-standing neglect. The room seemed to Winston to be a relic of a bygone age, untouched by the purges and the reforms of the past decades. The dim light from the lamp flickered, casting long shadows across the room, and Winston felt a sense of oppressive solitude. He wondered if this was where the Brotherhood, the mythical organization of anti-Party rebels, met, if such a group still existed and operated in secret, untouched by the Party's pervasive reach. The thought both excited and terrified him, stirring a dormant hope that there might be others who shared his loathing of the Party's tyranny. Yet, the very existence of such a group seemed improbable, given the Party's ruthless efficiency in rooting out dissent. As he stood there, pondering the possibility of rebellion, Winston was acutely aware of the telescreen on the opposite wall, its surface smooth and unblemished, its eye-like lens fixed unblinkingly upon him. The Party's watchfulness was absolute, its reach omnipresent, and the idea of resistance seemed as futile as it was daring. He resolved to hold onto that belief, no matter how bleak the reality might seem.

The room, filled with the acrid smell of tobacco, seemed to close in on him, yet he kept pacing, his steps measured and deliberate, as if the act of smoking and movement together could somehow unravel the knots in his mind. The others watched him, their expressions a mix of concern and curiosity, wondering what troubled the usually composed man. O'Brien's eyes, usually sharp and observant, were now clouded with worry, reflecting the turmoil within. He stopped pacing, the cigarette now a burnt stub, and looked at each person in the room, searching for an answer, a solution, or perhaps just a moment of understanding. His voice, when he finally spoke, was a mere whisper, laden with an emotion he struggled to name.

"Chúng ta sẽ bảo vệ tàu này và người dân chúng ta, dù bao nhiêu nguy hiểm", anh ta bày tỏ, cầm đầu điếu như một dấu hiệu sức mạnh của mình. Mọi người trên tàu nhìn thấy anh ta, cảm thấy tin tưởng và họ cũng tỏ ra sẵn sàng theo dõi lệnh của ông. O'Brien kiểm tra lại mọi người xung quanh, những người đang cố gắng tìm kiếm cách thoát khỏi vụ tai nạn hoặc những người đang lo lắng vì sự không rõ ràng của trường hợp. Anh ta nhìn thấy một phần đông người đang cố gắng tiếp cận vật dụng trong phòng khách, một số người đang nói chuyện nhau, cảm thấy lo lắng và không biết gì làm. "Hãy ngồi xuống và duy trì an toàn của bạn bè", O'Brien hỏi người dân, giúp đỡ họ tránh việc gây thiệt hại thêm cho tình hình. Anh ta sau đó dẫn dắt một số người tốt nhất có thể để họ giúp đỡ trong việc cung cấp first aid hoặc tìm kiếm các nguồn sự hỗ trợ từ bên ngoài tàu. Mặc dù không có thông tin về tình hình giao thông bên ngoài, O'Brien dù biết rằng việc cần phải đảm bảo an toàn cho tất cả người dân trên tàu là một nhiệm vụ cực kỳ đáng lo ngại. Anh ta cố gắng giải quyết vấn đề này một cách thông minh, dựa vào kinh nghiệm và khả năng trí tuệ của mình. Một lúc sau, ông ta bắt gặp một nhân viên hàng không trực tiếp thông báo về tình hình, cho biết họ sẽ đến sớm. Điều này giúp O'Brien biết rằng họ có thể giải quyết vấn đề này trong vòng thời gian sớm, và anh ta cũng đã đặt cho mình một mục tiêu cụ thể: cần phải đảm bảo rằng không có người bị thương nặng nề và cần phải chuẩn bị cho việc báo động tàu.

es_results_raw: habitación, contemplando los muros y pensando en su situación. Cada fumado le permitía al menos un momento de reflexión, un breve respiro de libertad en medio del caos que lo rodeaba. La habitación estaba fría, el aire pesado, y el solo sonido era el crujido de sus propios pasos. A medida que avanzaba, la luz del amanecer comenzaba a filtrar por las cortinas, iluminando la escena con un tono oscuro que reflejaba la dualidad de su existencia: la realidad tangible de su prisión y la realidad interior, su resistencia y esperanza perdida. Finalmente, llegó a la ventana, sus manos apoyadas contra el cristal, mirando hacia el horizonte donde se mezclaba el amanecer con las sombras de lo que había pasado. en_first_half: “You will have heard rumors of the existence of the Brotherhood. No doubt you have formed your own picture of it. You have imagined, probably, a huge underworld of conspirators, meeting secretly in cellars, scribbling messages on walls, recognizing one another by code words or by special movements of the hand. Nothing of the kind exists. The members of the Brotherhood have no way of recognizing one another, and it is impossible for any one member to be aware of the identity of more than a very few others. Goldstein himself, if he fell into the hands of the Thought Police, could not give them a complete list of members, or any information that would lead them to a complete list. No such list exists. The Brotherhood cannot be wiped out because it is not an organization in the ordinary sense. Nothing holds it together except an idea which is indestructible. You will never have anything to sustain you except the idea. You will get no comradeship and no encouragement. When finally you are caught, you will
en_second_half: get no help. We never help our members. At most, when it is absolutely necessary that someone should be silenced, we are occasionally able to smuggle a razor blade into a prisoner’s cell. You will have to get used to living without results and without hope. You will work for a while, you will be caught, you will confess, and then you will die. Those are the only results that you will ever see. There is no possibility that any perceptible change will happen within our own lifetime. We are the dead. Our only true life is in the future. We shall take part in it as handfuls of dust and splinters of bone. But how far away that future may be, there is no knowing. It might be a thousand years. At present nothing is possible except to extend the area of sanity little by little. We cannot act collectively. The lives of all those swarming faceless figures, all those blank faces in the streets of the city, all those natural fools on their way to the workhouse, can be snuffed out like that, just with a flick of your pen. It is a frightening thing when a man has the power to change the past, to abolish all records and facts which exist only in documents." The voice paused, and then continued: "You are afraid, I can see it. You are afraid of the future, of the unknown. But you need not be afraid. The future is certain. It is rigidly predetermined. The only freedom permitted to you is the freedom to obey."

en_first_half: The door opened, and another prisoner was brought in whose appearance sent a momentary chill through Winston. He was a commonplace, mean-looking man who might have been an engineer or technician of some kind. But what was
en_second_half: startling was the emaciation of his face. It was like a skull. Because of its thinness the mouth and eyes looked disproportionately large, and the eyes seemed filled with a murderous, unappeasable hatred of somebody or something.
en_results: completion> to be most disturbing was the fact that he was wearing the blue uniform of the Inner Party. His face was sallow, and his eyes had a dead, fishy look. He was escorted by two guards, who flanked him closely, their truncheons
en_results_raw: completion> to be most disturbing was the fact that he was wearing the blue uniform of the Inner Party. His face was sallow, and his eyes had a dead, fishy look. He was escorted by two guards, who flanked him closely, their truncheons ready. The prisoner's lips moved almost imperceptibly, as though he were whispering to himself. The room fell silent, all eyes fixed on the newcomer, sensing that something significant was about to be revealed. Winston felt a tightening in his chest, an instinctive fear that seemed to have no rational basis, yet was as strong as if it had been communicated to him by some deeper, nameless part of his being. The prisoner was led to the center of the room, where a chair awaited him. The guards roughly pushed him down into it, and the man's body slumped, his head coming to rest against the back of the chair. The silence in the room was oppressive, broken only by the sound of Winston's own breathing, which seemed unnaturally loud in the stillness. The Party official who had brought the prisoner in now stepped forward, his expression unreadable. He cleared his throat, signaling the beginning of the interrogation that everyone in the room knew was inevitable. "You have been brought here," he began, his voice cold and precise, "to answer for your crimes against the Party. You will confess, and you will recant your heresies. Do you understand?" The prisoner's lips moved again, but no sound emerged. His eyes, however, flickered with a brief, defiant spark before they dulled once more. The official's gaze hardened. "I see," he said, as if this lack of response was exactly what he had expected. "We will proceed without your cooperation then." He turned to the guards. "Begin with the prelude." The guards stepped forward, their truncheons raised menacingly. The room filled with a tension so thick it could be cut with a knife, as all eyes remained fixed on the prisoner, waiting to see how he would endure the first blows.

La verdad es lo que realmente te matará aquí. Y yo... yo soy el guardia de la verdad que no puedes escapar de." Su palabras eran como un viento frío que se infiltraba en la sangre de Winston, llenándolo de una desesperanza aún mayor. Winston sintió cómo sus manos se llenaban de sudor, y un temor crecía en el estómago, un temor que no había sentido desde que entró en este lugar. El hombre se acercó aún más, y Winston notó el olor a humedad y tierra que emanaba de sus ropa, un olor que parecía emanar de la tierra misma, de los años de encarcelamiento y abandono. "Te voy a enseñar, Winston, qué significa ser verdadero en un mundo de mentiras," continuó el hombre, su voz ahora casi un susurro, pero aún más intimidante por su intensidad. "Y después de todo, quizás te sorprenda saber que yo... yo soy parte de esa verdad que tanto temes." Su mirada se enraizó aún más, y Winston sintió cómo cada palabra era como un golpe directo al corazón. La oscuridad del cuarto parecía engolirlo, y el miedo se apoderaba de su espíritu. "Así que escucha atentamente, Winston," concluyó el hombre, su voz ahora casi un susurro, "porque pronto encontrarás que la verdad es lo más peligrosa de todas las mentiras." El silencio volvió a dominar el cuarto, pero ahora era un silencio cargado de tensiones invisibles, un silencio que parecía hablar más que las palabras. Winston permaneció estirado en su cama, intentando procesar lo que había escuchado, su mente luchando entre la incredulidad y el temor. El hombre se alejó lentamente, su figura retorcida por la luz poca del pasillo, antes de desaparecer completamente. Y en ese instante, Winston comprendió que su vida había cambiado para siempre.

He could hear the distant sounds of chaos – the wailing of sirens, the shouting of voices, the crash of falling debris. Winston's mind raced to catch up with the events, piecing together the implications of what he had just experienced. It was a weapon, he was certain of it – a new, terrifying form of warfare that could incapacitate without touching, could destroy without sound. The Party would surely use such a weapon to maintain its iron grip on Oceania, to crush any flicker of rebellion before it could ignite into a flame. He had to warn the others, to organize some form of resistance, but first, he needed to find solid ground beneath him, to steady his trembling hands, and to clear the fog that seemed to cloud his thoughts. He knew he had to act, but the enormity of the situation threatened to overwhelm him. He lay there for a moment longer, grappling with the reality that the world as he knew it had irrevocably changed.

en_second_half: the statement, “You do not exist,” contain a logical absurdity? But what use was it to say so? His mind shriveled as he thought of the unanswerable, mad arguments with which O’Brien would demolish him.
en_results: the very fact that he could think at all imply a certain reality to his thoughts, a reality which could not be denied without falling into self-contradiction? His mind, a product of whatever substance or
en_results_raw: the very fact that he could think at all imply a certain reality to his thoughts, a reality which could not be denied without falling into self-contradiction? His mind, a product of whatever substance or energy constituted his being, could not be dismissed as an illusion unless it were to contradict its own existence. The very act of doubting his existence presupposed the existence of the faculty of thought, which in turn implied a certain level of being. Moreover, the external world, with its tangible objects and perceivable laws, continued to operate independently of his contemplation of it. If he were truly nothing, then the laws of physics, the continuity of time, and the interactions of matter would all collapse into chaos, which they clearly did not. Thus, his existence, though perhaps not in the traditional sense of a permanent, unchanging self, was implied by the very fabric of his experiences and the consistent operation of the universe around him.

en_results_raw: and there is acceptance.” O’Brien’s voice carried a weight that seemed to fill the room, each word resonating with the gravity of the process I was about to undergo. The first stage, learning, was akin to being submerged in a vast ocean of knowledge, where every drop was a new piece of information, a new skill to master. It required focus, dedication, and an open mind, as I was to absorb the complexities of my situation and the world around me. Understanding, the second stage, was like peeling back the layers of an onion, revealing the multifaceted nature of reality and my place within it. It demanded introspection, questioning, and a willingness to confront uncomfortable truths about myself and my past actions. Only after these stages could one hope to reach the third stage, acceptance. Acceptance was not merely the acknowledgment of facts or the resignation to one’s circumstances; it was a profound internal shift, a reconciliation with the self and the world. It was the moment when one could look in the mirror and see not just a reflection, but a person whole and at peace with their identity and history. This journey, as O’Brien implied, was not an easy one, but it was a necessary path toward healing and wholeness.

Podríamos incluso considerar que nuestro interés en las estrellas es una metafórica expresión de nuestro deseo de comprender y conectarnos con algo más grande que nosotros mismos. Anh ta phải tiếp tục đi dù băng hoặc mưa, vì mục tiêu cuối cùng là quan trọng hơn bất kỳ thứ gì. "Chúng ta cần tìm cách vượt qua đi", O'Brien nhấn mạnh, cảm thấy áp lực từ bên trong và bên ngoài. "Điều quan trọng là chúng ta không bao giờ bỏ cuộc". Anh ta nhìn lên mặt trời, đang bị mưa bao lau, nhưng cũng có thêm sức mạnh từ những người bạn cùng đi dù chơi. Đó là sức mạnh chung mà họ sẽ cần để vượt qua những khó khăn đang đến. Anh ta cảm thấy họ cần phải đoàn kết và tuân thủ mục tiêu, dù đối mặt với những thử thách nào đó. Mọi việc sẽ đơn giản hơn nếu họ vẫn tin vào nhau và không để thay đổi. O'Brien cố gắng nhớ lại lời nguyện của mình, với sự tin tưởng rằng họ sẽ đạt được mục tiêu cuối cùng, dù bao giờ cũng khó khăn. Anh ta bước lên, mưa vừa mát mẻ và vừa lạnh lắm, nhưng anh ta không chịu bao giờ bỏ cuộc. Mục tiêu đang gần đến, và anh ta sẽ vượt qua mọi khó khăn để thực hiện nó. "Chúng ta sẽ đi đến", O'Brien nói lên, cảm thấy cảm hứng và lòng kiên trì, dù mưa vẫn tiếng rung trên cầu đường. "Tôi sẽ đảm bảo chúng ta không bỏ cuộc". Anh ta tiếp tục đi, mọi việc sẽ được giải quyết, vì anh ta đã quyết tâm. Mục tiêu sẽ đến, và anh ta sẽ là người dẫn đầu.

You would wake up in the middle of the night, sweating and terrified, with the pebble clenched tight in your fist. You would lie there, unable to move, listening to the sound of your own breathing and the distant, muffled roar that seemed to come from inside your own head. Gradually, the panic would subside, and you would fall back asleep, only to have the dream return in a few hours. Over time, the dreams became less frequent, and the pebble in your hand seemed to grow smaller and less menacing. Eventually, they stopped altogether, and you thought you had conquered that particular fear. But now, as you stood in the dimly lit room, facing O'Brien, you realized that the dreams had not been about failure or punishment. They had been about loss - the loss of your own identity, the loss of your past, the loss of the person you used to be. And as O'Brien spoke those words, you felt a cold dread settle in the pit of your stomach, a dread that was far more terrifying than any dream.

en_first_half: There was an outburst of squeals from the cage. It seemed to reach Winston from far away. The rats were fighting; they were trying

en_results: to bite each other. The sight of their sharp teeth, glistening with saliva, and the frenzied movements of their bodies filled Winston
en_results_raw: to bite each other. The sight of their sharp teeth, glistening with saliva, and the frenzied movements of their bodies filled Winston with a deep-seated fear. He had always been terrified of rats, a phobia that dated back to his childhood when he had been chased by a large rat in a crowded market. Now, trapped in this room, the sound of their struggle seemed to echo in his head, amplifying his panic. The air felt thick, heavy with the stench of fear and the musk of the animals. He could almost feel their breath on his neck, their cold, wet noses sniffing at his skin. The thought of one of those rats escaping and scurrying up his trouser leg sent a shiver down his spine. He knew that if the rats continued to fight like this, one might get injured, and he dreaded the thought of what would happen next. The Party had methods for dealing with disobedience, and Winston knew all too well what they involved. The rats, with their unpredictable nature and ability to burrow into the darkest, most hidden places, were a perfect symbol of the Party's invasive reach. They could be used to instill terror, to break the spirit of the most resilient dissident. In that moment, Winston's resolve wavered, the noise from the cage making it difficult to think clearly. He wondered if he had been foolish to ever believe he could stand against the Party. The squeals seemed to mock his rebellion, a cruel reminder of the power the Party held over even the most intimate fears.

en_first_half: It must have been about a month before she disappeared. It was a moment of reconciliation, when the nagging hunger in his belly was forgotten and his earlier affection for her had temporarily revived. He remembered the day well, a pelting, drenching day when the water streamed down the window pane and the light indoors was too dull to read by. The boredom of the two children in the dark, cramped bedroom became unbearable. Winston whined and grizzled, made futile demands for food, fretted about the room, pulling everything out of place and kicking the wainscoting until the neighbors banged on the wall, while the younger child wailed intermittently. In the end his mother said, “Now be good, and I’ll buy you a toy. A lovely toy—you’ll love it”; and then she had gone out in the rain, to a little general shop which was still sporadically open near by, and come
en_second_half: back with a cardboard box containing an outfit of Snakes and Ladders. He could still remember the smell of the damp cardboard. It was a miserable outfit. The board was cracked and the tiny wooden dice were so ill-cut that they would hardly lie on their sides. Winston looked at the thing sulkily and without interest. But then his mother lit a piece of candle and they sat down on the floor to play. Soon he was wildly excited and shouting with laughter as the tiddlywinks climbed hopefully up the ladders and then came slithering down the snakes again, almost back to the starting point. They played eight games, winning four each. His tiny sister, too young to understand what the game was about, had sat propped up against a bolster, laughing because the others were laughing. For a whole afternoon they had all been happy together, as in his earlier childhood.

The clock on the wall showed half-past ten. He lay there for a few moments, gathering together his scattered thoughts. The dream had been a foolish one. It was foolish to imagine that one could ever escape the eye of the Party. The telescreen, the omnipresent observer and auditor, was everywhere. Its pale blue surface covered every wall, even in his own home. It watched you or, as Winston had come to believe, it could watch you even when it was turned off. The Party's power was absolute, its grip unyielding. The dream of rebellion, of secret meetings and conspiracies, was just that—a dream. The reality was stark and unyielding. The Party's control was total, its ideology absolute. There was no room for dissent, no space for individual thought. The past was erased, the outside world nonexistent, and the present was a continuous, unyielding stream of propaganda and work. The voice from the telescreen, though now quieter, continued its relentless narrative, a reminder of the Party's omnipresence and the unyielding nature of its control. Winston, rubbing the sleep from his eyes, knew that he must soon rejoin the world outside. The Ministry of Truth awaited him, as did his humdrum job of rewriting historical records to match the Party's ever-changing narrative. The gin, which had momentarily dulled the edges of his reality, would soon wear off, leaving him to face another day under the watchful eye of Big Brother.
